content.description:
Another fine line for the new climber. Not too steep, big holds, and not very tall.

Be sure to extend your toprope anchor using a long sling.
content.protection: Small gear for the climb. Sling a tree for the climb. Can be backed up with a large hex.
content.location: Dead center of the Toad wall. Take the line straight up, top out, and build a toprope anchor.

content.description:
This is the best and most obvious line on the wall. Steep-ish, on giant holds--this route is perfect for brand new climbers who want something other than slab.

Extend your anchor. Use the sturdy tree and back it up with gear.

This is the closest it gets to climbing a ladder--but more fun!
content.protection: Small to medium gear. Slings for patina plates.
content.location: Steepest portion of the wall, parallel to the bright orange streak.

content.description:
This is the easiest way to the top of Toad Rock. A gear-protected 5.0 that tops out on a cool formation. Excellent first time climb (if you sufficiently extend your anchor; otherwise, your rope drag will be considerable).

After topping out, many opportunities exist for an anchor. For this route, the nice long horizontal crack works well.
content.protection: Bring some gear to protect the climb, if inclined, and some medium cams and nuts for a toprope anchor.
content.location: Start on the low-angle slab and trend right as you head up. Climb/scramble around the steeper blocks. This may feel like 4th class terrain.
